channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Police say London stabbing of Hasidic rabbi NOT a terror attack
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Yaakov Schlesinger, a senior rabbi and teacher from the Satmar sect, was taken to hospital after being stabbed multiple times in Stoke Newington, north London.

item.title: BLM activists DEFY Boris Johnson's calls to abandon protests
item.description: The show of defiance comes despite the Prime Minister warning a 'growing minority' of 'extremists' have hijacked the BLM cause.

item.title: Social media is 'fuelling prejudice' against Chinese people during pandemic, study claims
item.description: People who trust what they see on social media are more likely to hold prejudiced views against Chinese people during the coronavirus pandemic, a new study suggests.

item.title: Suspects charged with attacking Hackney police appear at court
item.description: Marvin Henderson (pictured), 34, Jordan Thomas, 20, and Paul Kabemba, 33, from Hackney, East London, appeared at Thames Magistrates Court on Friday.

item.title: Meghan Markle 'mortified' over friend Jessica Mulroney's threats
item.description: Meghan Markle is telling close friends she is 'absolutely mortified' over best friend Jessica Mulroney's 'tone-deaf' and 'heatbreaking' actions, close friends tell DailyMail.com.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Parents urge German police to share evidence
item.description: Gerry and Kate McCann have been given no reason why police have dubbed the investigation into Madeleine McCann's disappearance a murder hunt rather than a missing person inquiry.

item.title: Now UKTV will REINSTATE Fawlty Towers 'don't mention the war' episode
item.description: Fawlty Towers episode The Germans - fondly remembered for the line 'don't mention the War' - will return to UKTV platform with warnings highlighting 'potentially offensive content'.

item.title: Russian oligarch's son loses cash secrecy fight with mother
item.description: Trader Temur Akhmedov, 26, based in London, wanted to bar reporters from revealing details of his personal finance, but a High Court judge today refused to make the orders he wanted.

item.title: Coronavirus: Quality of sleep has dropped during lockdown
item.description: Researchers from the University of Basel surveyed 435 individuals between 23 March and 26 April 2020. on how the lockdown has influenced their sleep cycles.

item.title: Anna Wintour ruthlessly mocked others for their looks, former friend reveals
item.description: New York Times bestselling author Jerry Oppenheimer writes Anna Wintour has long been thought of 'hurtful and intolerant', dating back to her teens in London.

item.title: Mother reveals the ugly truths of parenthood in new book
item.description: Rebecca Oxtoby, 29, from Warrington, is the proud mother of Isabelle, 11 months. In her book Mum's the Word, she gets brutally honestly about the ugly truth of motherhood.

item.title: ABC cuts ties with Jessica Mulroney after she threatened to sue black influencer
item.description: DailyMail.com exclusively learned on Friday that Mulroney would never be returning to her occasional role as a fashion contributor on Good Morning America.

item.title: Police close A-road to allow funeral cortege to pass including Rolls-Royce once owned Simon Cowell
item.description: The funeral, for Albert Joseph Harper, who died aged 47, took place on Wednesday morning at Portfield Cemetery, in Chichester, West Sussex.

item.title: Calls for Guardian to be shut for 1862 backing of Confederates
item.description: The newspaper, which was then called the Manchester Guardian, sided with the Confederates in the US Civil War against the President, who wanted slavery abolished.

item.title: Couple become the first in Britain to be sentenced for possessing a chemical weapon
item.description: Martyn Tasker, 40 and wife Michaela, 31 from Lincoln, are thought to be the first in the UK to be sentenced for possessing a chemical weapon. The clean-up of the lake cost the tax-payer almost £300,000.

item.title: Britons must continue to remain two metres apart, experts tell Government scientific advisers
item.description: The UK must stick to the two-metre social distancing rule as reducing it to one-metre could increase the risk of infection tenfold, Government advisers have been warned.

item.title: Donald Trump calls Seattle BLM protestors 'terrorists'
item.description: Trump tweeted on Friday: 'Seattle Mayor says, about the anarchists takeover of her city, "it is a Summer of Love". 'These Liberal Dems don't have a clue. The terrorists burn and pillage our cities.'

item.title: Barnsley street evacuated street as police find suspicious items
item.description: An entire street in Grimthorpe, Barnsley was evacuated after suspicious items were found in a house on Friday, with police and Army bomb disposal officials being called to the scene.

item.title: Fears of a coronavirus second wave in South Korea
item.description: The country's top infectious disease expert is worried about the speed of virus transmissions in the capital, where around 30 to 50 new infections have been reported each day since late May.

item.title: M&S sends shoppers into frenzy after they re-stock their summer beauty bag
item.description: British retailer Marks and Spencer has restocked its sell-out Summer Beauty Bag offering containing £110 worth of beauty products for just £15 and it has sent excited shoppers into frenzy.

item.title: Vandals attack Bristol statue of black playwright with bleach
item.description: Avon and Somerset Police are investigating the bleach attack on the statue of black playwright Alfred Fagon, which was erected in 1987 in the St Pauls area of Bristol a year after his death.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Reports expect outbreak to carry on into 2021
item.description: Reports presented to members of SAGE, the UK Government's scientific advisory group, said in March that social distancing measures would have to carry on for a year or more.

item.title: Melania Trump only moved to the White House AFTER getting a new prenup
item.description: Melania Trump used her position as first lady to renegotiate her prenup with Donald Trump, ensured Barron would be treated the same as the eldest Trump children, and has had plastic surgery.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Uber drivers and passengers must wear masks
item.description: Uber has confirmed that drivers and passengers across the UK must wear face coverings during journeys from Monday, in line with government policy.

item.title: Pretty in pink: India crater lake changes colour overnight
item.description: India's Lonar Lake, which formed by a meteorite 50,000 years ago, changed from green to pink overnight. Experts say it may be caused by high salinity in the water or the presence of algae.

item.title: Study shows 'older organised worriers' scared of COVID-19 most likely to panic buy loo roll
item.description: As the deadly virus took hold of Europe and North America in March, panic buyers forced toilet roll sales to surge by up to 700 per cent, companies reported.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sweden and Poland last European countries to peak
item.description: Sweden and Poland's 14-day incidence since Europe's peak on April 9 was at its highest level. Other EU countries' 14-day incidence has declined by 80 per cent because of lockdowns.

item.title: Grant Shapps appeals to commuters ahead of new face coverings rule
item.description: The Transport Secretary said it should become the new normal for people to pick up their face covering when they go outside if they intend to get on a bus, train or the tube.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 41,481 with 202 new fatalities
item.description: Today's death figure marks the lowest rise on a Friday since March 20, three days before the country went into lockdown, when there were just 36 coronavirus fatalities.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan say they are 'deeply shaken by Trump's rhetoric'
item.description: On Thursday, Facebook billionaire Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan responded to a letter criticizing the social media platform's moderation policies regarding President Trump.

item.title: High streets prepare for manic Monday as chains such as Primark and John Lewis prepare to reopen
item.description: Major high street retailers like Primark, M&S and JD Sports are all set to reopen on Monday after the government finally gave the green light for shops to reopen after the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Fury as Keir Starmer stays SILENT over 'vile' Priti Patel letter from Labour MPs
item.description: Labour leader Keir Starmer has refused to criticise the letter, signed by frontbenchers, despite a wave of outrage and fury from the Home Secretary.

item.title: Emily Sheffield following George Osborne into the Evening Standard editor's chair
item.description: David Cameron's sister-in-law Emily Sheffield will take over from George Osborne as editor of the Evening Standard. Ms Sheffield has never shied away from airing her own political views.

item.title: Two women jailed for attacking police during house party raid and making coronavirus threat
item.description: Two women who attacked police at a lockdown house party in Eastbourne have been jailed, following an altercation which saw an officer threatened with the possible transfer of coronavirus.
item.media:description: Millie Robinson was jailed along with Bayleigh Meadows (police handout/PA)

item.title: National Trust removes the semi-naked statue of a black man
item.description: This statue outside Dunham Massey Hall in Cheshire has been removed by the National Trust following the controversy surrounding the public honouring of slave owners.

item.title: Number of celibate young people DOUBLED in last 20 years
item.description: Almost 10,000 Americans were quizzed on their sexual antics as part of a study run by scientists at the Karolinska Institute in Sweden.

item.title: Diabetes sufferers up to four times more likely to break a bone
item.description: Experts found that Type 1 diabetics are the most likely to suffer a fracture - but Type 2 patients are still a third more likely than non-diabetics to break something.

item.title: Nurse who didn't back Cummings axed from coronavirus broadcast
item.description: The Chief Nursing Officer for England, was reportedly asked her views on the controversy surrounding the powerful Downing Street aide and was blocked from a TV appearance.

item.title: 'Germans' episode of Fawlty Towers is taken off-air
item.description: The actor, 80, who played Basil Fawlty, branded the BBC-owned channel 'stupid' for not realising The Germans was mocking racist people.

item.title: Boris Johnson slams Sadiq Khan for boarding up Churchill statue
item.description: Workers were pictured putting up scaffolding around Churchill's statue at Parliament Square and the nearby Cenotaph late on Thursday evening

item.title: Sarah Paulson and Aaron Paul team up with NAACP for an I Take Responsibility PSA video
item.description: Comedian Ricky Gervais has skewered a group of celebrities who are receiving backlash for taking part in a PSA on white privilege that has been described as 'cringe-inducing'

item.title: Delivery driver chased away by territorial TURKEY
item.description: Trev the turkey, aged three, showed the DPD driver who was boss during a parcel drop-off at his home in Winchcombe in the Cotswolds. The driver abandoned the parcels in the driveway.

item.title: Fears for proposed £300k Margaret Thatcher statue in Grantham
item.description: Sixteen months after the statue (artist's impression, pictured) was approved by councillors in Margaret Thatcher's home town of Grantham, Lincolnshire, the plinth on which it will stand still remains empty.

item.title: Prince Charles and Camilla will be the first royals to leave lockdown next week
item.description: The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall will be the first members of the royal family to leave lockdown when they welcome French President Emmanuel Macron to the UK next Thursday.

item.title: GDP plummeted by 20.4 PER CENT in April amid coronavirus chaos
item.description: GDP plummeted by more than a fifth in the first month of lockdown, and has now contracted by 25 per cent since February.

item.title: Prince Andrew holds the cards as the US pursues sex probe
item.description: Former US federal prosecutor David Weinstein said making a request through the UK government could put pressure on Prince Andrew to help but he couldn't be forced to.

item.title: Activists remove statue of Belgium's King Leopold II in Brussels
item.description: The figure vanished from its plinth during Thursday night, Belgian broadcaster RTBF reported, leaving an empty stand in the Auderghem neighbourhood on Friday.

item.title: Strictly star Anton Du Beke's son George, 3, is rushed to hospital for an operation
item.description: Anton Du Beke's son George, 3, is rushed to hospital for an operation as Strictly star cancels dance classes to be by his side

item.title: Millions of microplastic particles found raining down on US national parks
item.description: Researchers from Utah State University used high-resolution equipment to discover samples of this plastic pollution that had rained down from the atmosphere.

item.title: Apple's Siri gives info on BLM when users say 'All Lives Matter'
item.description: Apple's Siri is supporting the Black Lives Matter movement by providing users who say 'All Lives Matter' with a statement and a link to learn more about human rights initiative.

item.title: Beachgoers are stunned to find a 14-foot-long giant squid washed up on the shore in South Africa
item.description: Jaw-dropping footage of the giant squid was captured by eye witnesses and it shows the amazing scale of the 440lb sea monster as its tentacles spread out across the beach.

item.title: 'Behemoth' 115 million-year-old ammonite is found on a beach in the Isle of Wight
item.description: The ammonite was spotted and pried loose of surrounding rock by university students Jack Wonfor, 19, and Theo Vickers, 21, at Chale Bay.

item.title: Sky Sports 'Choose a Chant' feature will allow viewers to play songs during live games
item.description: The added 'Choose a Chant' feature will be available in their Fanzone and Watchalong options for their coverage of the Premier League, which returns to our screens on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince Albert of Monaco's first cousin Baroness Elizabeth-Ann dies aged 73
item.description: Monaco's royal family confirmed the passing of Baroness Elizabeth-Ann de Massy on Facebook, announcing that she had died at Princess Grace Hospital in Monaco on Wednesday evening.

item.title: Zahra Shah: First picture of girl 'tortured to death' in Pakistan emerges
item.description: Hassan Siddiqui and his wife, who has not been named, are being held in jail in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, awaiting a lie detector test for allegedly beating Zahra Shah (pictured) to death.

item.title: Davina McCall moves into new £3.4 million home to make 'fresh start' after Matthew Robertson split
item.description: The TV presenter, 52, appeared to have finally finished renovations on the house as she was spotted moving to the £3.4 million house on Wednesday.

item.title: Suffolk Police apologise for `racist´ comments from officers
item.description: Suffolk Police have issued a public apology after two of its officers, one of whom is pictured here, stopped a middle-aged black couple because they were 'driving a motor vehicle on a road'.
item.media:description: One of the officers involved in the incident (@maobxby/PA)

item.title: Meet the adorable fluffy bi-colour cat the Internet is swooning over
item.description: Cat, a 21-month-old feline from Thailand, has white fur on one side of her face and grey on the other, prompting her owner, Eve, to joke that she looks like Batman villain Harvey Dent, AKA Two-Face.

item.title: Doctors are testing whether survivors' plasma can prevent coronavirus infection
item.description: Coronavirus patients are being experimentally treated with plasma donated by survivors. Now, Johns Hopkins University researchers are testing whether plasma can prevent COVID-19.
item.media:description: In this April 22, 2020 photo provided by New York Blood Center Enterprises, Aubrie Cresswell, 24, donates convalescent plasma at the Blood Bank of Delmarva Christiana Donor Center in suburban Newark, Del. "It's, I think, our job as humans to step forward and help in society," said Cresswell who has donated three times and counting. One donation was shipped to a hospitalized friend of a friend, and "it brought me to tears. I was like, overwhelmed with it just because the family was really thankful." (New York Blood Center Enterprises via AP)

item.title: Coronavirus: UK economy hit harder than European counterparts
item.description: The UK economy is faring worse than the economies of Germany, France and Italy across several key sectors, according to comparable data published by each country.

item.title: Will Princess Anne, 69, be the FIRST royal to return to work in-person?
item.description: The Princess Royal, 69, who is currently isolating at Gatcombe Park in Surrey, may become the first member of The Firm to return to working in-person, with a scheduled appointment next week.

item.title: Three men and boy, 13, to face court charged with attacking police in Hackney
item.description: A video of the incident, which left two officers with minor injuries was widely circulated on social media, and drew widespread condemnation from police chiefs and Home Secretary Priti Patel.

item.title: George Osborne steps down as editor from Evening Standard
item.description: Emily Sheffield, a former deputy editor of Vogue and current paper columnist, will take the reins on July 1 when Mr Osborne becomes editor-in-chief.

item.title: Bristol University to review logo after Colston statue toppled
item.description: Bristol vice-chancellor and president Professor Hugh Brady said racism was 'still very much part of everyday life' but he was looking to play an 'active' part in stamping it out.

item.title: Meghan Markle has 'great ideas' and 'always gets involved in dressing' Smart Works clients
item.description: CEO Kate Stephens told The Flock that the Duchess of Sussex, 38, is 'absolutely still involved' with her patronage Smart Works, despite stepping back from royal duty at the end of March.

item.title: UK teeters on brink of anarchy during a national emergency
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: A policeman grapples with a black suspect on an East London pavement. Instead of rushing to the copper's aid, passers-by attack him. Priti 'Flamingo' Patel described it as 'sickening'.

item.title: Greene King announces 'safe socialising' layout for its 1,700 pubs ahead of their July 4 reopening
item.description: The UK pub giant said it has invested £15million into pub safety, including protective measures for staff and customers such as Perspex screens and visors.

item.title: Michael Gove 'formally' tells EU transition ends in December despite Scots and Welsh delay demands
item.description: He made the announcement as Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and her Welsh counterpart Mark Drakeford demanded that the post-Brexit transition extend into 2021.

item.title: Police say two sisters murdered in a London beauty spot were stabbed to death by a stranger
item.description: Officers investigating the north-west London murder case are trawling through a nearby refuse depot in search of 'items of relevance' accidentally cleared when mistaken for rubbish.

item.title: Ex-officer bribed with £10k to tip off crime gangs about police
item.description: Stephen Cloney was once commended for his anti-terror work, but after becoming 'bored' at being moved to a humdrum desk job, he mined Merseyside Police computers for cash.

item.title: Sony reveals PlayStation 5 designs and new lineup of games
item.description: Sony has officially unveiled the PlayStation 5, the company's next generation gaming console planned for launch 'later this year,' along with a lineup of new games and updates to old franchises.

item.title: Cardiff bride's wedding 'ruined' by brother's drug-fuelled brawl
item.description: A bride's wedding day was ruined after her brother was spotted sniffing cocaine at the plush wedding reception on the Gower, South Wales, before attacking one of the guests with a pint glass.

item.title: Care homes were an 'afterthought' during coronavirus response, damning report
item.description: The National Audit Office (NAO) report - the first independent review of preparations for the pandemic - said at care homes were 'at the back of the queue' during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Testing data estimates only 33,000 infected
item.description: Results from population testing by the Office for National Statistics suggest just 0.06 per cent of the population of England currently has the coronavirus, down from 0.1 per cent last week.

item.title: UK to enjoy 79F heatwave from tomorrow as lockdown eases
item.description: Britons will finally be able to reunite with loved ones from tomorrow after Boris Johnson gave the green light for two households to merge into 'support bubbles'.

item.title: New TikTok trend where parents spill water on their crying babies branded 'mean'
item.description: A new viral trend which taking over TikTok has divided parents across the globe, with some branding it 'cruel'. The challenge involves mothers spraying their surprised babies with water.

item.title: Norwegian jewel store thieves smashed off moped by police after high-speed chase through a PARK
item.description: The car chase happened after two thieves raided a jewellery shop in Norway's capital city of Oslo in broad daylight.

item.title: Crime recorded by the Met Police RISES by 8,000 offences compared to previous month
item.description: In May the total recorded offences went back up to 56,514, according to figures published on the force's crime data dashboard. Strict lockdown measures were eased in England in mid-May.

item.title: Facebook bans woman for sharing her colourised World War Two images that showed Hitler and Goering
item.description: Olga Shirnina Russia, Moscow, said a series of photos, bought to life and posted to her 23,000 followers, were removed by Facebook for breaching 'Community Standards'.

item.title: Police protest across France over ban on chokeholds in the wake of George Floyd's death
item.description: Officers marched along the Champs Elysees boulevard to the interior ministry in Paris on Friday, accusing the government of scapegoating law enforcement agencies as public anger swells.

item.title: Baden-Powell statue will be boarded-up after Bournemouth council U-turned on removing it
item.description: Civic chiefs had previously agreed to take down the 5ft tall bronze statue of Scout founder Robert Baden-Powell in Poole Quay amid fears it would be targeted by Black Lives Matter protesters.

item.title: Graffiti vandals attack Robert the Bruce statue in Scotland branding him a 'racist king'
item.description: The monument at the Battle of Bannockburn site near Stirling (pictured) was found this morning daubed with white paint which also read 'BLM'.

item.title: Blundering German police 'TOLD Madeleine McCann suspect he was going to be investigated'
item.description: The suspect, who has been identified as Christian Brueckner, has a history of previous sex offences including child abuse and rape.

item.title: Hampton Court and Hillsborough Palace to open next week
item.description: Hampton Court Palace, in London, and Hillsborough Castle, in Northern Ireland, will open their gates on 18 June. The sites are managed by Historic Royal Palaces, which has been hard hit by COVID-19.

item.title: Workmen find magazine from 1895 hidden inside Edward Colston statue signed by men who erected it
item.description: After being fished-out from Bristol Harbour, where it was thrown into by protesters on Sunday, museum workers found a magazine from 1895 inside the Edward Colston statue.

item.title: Virginia Roberts admitted to the hospital with bacterial meningitis
item.description: Virginia Roberts, 36, tweeted from her hospital bed early Friday, saying she's been ill with bacterial meningitis for the past three days after returning from a trip to the rainforest.

item.title: Coronavirus: Financial markets drop amid fears of second wave
item.description: The grim global picture comes as it emerged today that Covid-19 forced the UK economy to shrink by an astonishing 20.4 per cent in April - the biggest fall ever.

item.title: Dundee Labour councillor urges colleagues to stop using phrase 'nitty gritty' in meetings
item.description: The phrase, which is thought to have originated from the 18th century and was used as another term for slaves, is part of the lexicon councillor Georgia Cruickshank is attempting to put a stop to.

item.title: This Is Us writer Jas Waters, 39, died from suicide by hanging
item.description: The news comes one day after This Is Us stars revealed the writer's passing as they posted tributes to her on social media. Waters had contributed to 18 episodes of the hit NBC drama.

item.title: Man, 60, sits dead on train for FIVE HOURS after heart attack
item.description: A passenger who suffered a heart attack on a cross country train from Manchester Piccadilly to Bournemouth sat dead for more than five hours before being discovered by a cleaner.

item.title: Thugs armed with metal poles and cricket bats battle each other in the street in Walsall
item.description: Two men were taken to hospital and another man remains in police custody after being arrested on suspicion of wounding during a brawl on a residential road in Walsall, West Midlands.

item.title: Nigel Farage 'was dropped by LBC amid staff backlash'
item.description: Mr Farage was back on air this morning on a rival radio station and stuck by criticism of anti-racism activists, which he branded a 'Marxist anarchist mob'.

item.title: Priti Patel orders clampdown on violent protesters amid unrest
item.description: The Home Secretary and Justice Secretary Robert Buckland are plotting a response to protests based on the 2011 London riots, urging magistrates' courts to extend opening hours and fast-track cases.

item.title: Demise of BOGOF deals and other promotions pushes grocery prices up 2.4 per cent in a MONTH
item.description: Prices rocketed up between March 18 and April 17 as the impact of the disease became apparent and consumers began to panic buy essentials like toilet paper, pasta and flour.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Interactive map shows London worst hit area
item.description: The map, which uses Office for National Statistics data, revealed London has suffered 138 Covid deaths per 100,000 people - almost double the national average of 81 fatalities.

item.title: JK Rowling's ex-husband is pictured for first time since he said: 'I slapped her but I'm not sorry'
item.description: Jorges Arantes stepped out from his modest flat in the Portuguese city of Porto wearing a face mask and glasses (pictured).

item.title: Compulsory use of facemasks can slash spread of coronavirus by 40%, study claims
item.description: The study, in Germany, examined the growth rate of cases in regions across the country in the days following the introduction of masks in shops and on public transport.

item.title: Editor of world's biggest Harry Potter fan site urges people to stop buying JK Rowling's books
item.description: Melissa Anelli, who runs The Leaky Couldron, pointed her 28,000 followers to a post from a Harry Potter podcast, which offered 'a guide to cancelling' the author.

item.title: Kate Middleton 'is very keen to stop the constant comparisons between herself and Meghan Markle'
item.description: Duncan Larcombe, a former royal editor, told New magazine that Kate was particularly upset by the article because she is 'very keen' to stop comparisons between herself and Meghan.

item.title: Couple who constantly homeschool their children leave viewers divided on Britain's Best Parent
item.description: Creative inventor Ben and stay-at-home mother Becky, from Wiltshire, are parents to three girls - Daisy, 10, Lauren, 8, and Arabella, 5 - and insist youngsters should never stop learning.

item.title: People are left horrified after watching kinky movie 365 DNI with parents
item.description: Polish erotic film 365 DNI launched on Netflix on Sunday to much fanfare. The film sees a businesswoman imprisoned by a mafia boss against her will.

item.title: Middlesbrough mayor is slammed for post saying poverty is more of an issue than white privilege
item.description: Andy Preston's suggestion that poverty is the more poignant issue comes amid widespread Black Lives Matter protests, and Facebook users have labelled the post as 'offensive'.

item.title: Greater access to water and sewer networks could help gigabit rollout
item.description: Government plans could see a regulation change that would force utility firms to open their infrastructure such as pipes and sewers for new superfast internet cables.
item.media:description: Government exploring ways equipment can be carried through `passive´ infrastructure owned by other telecoms companies, as well as energy networks (Rui Vieira/PA)

item.title: Duchess of Cornwall poses in a Wendy house built for Princess Elizabeth at Birkhall
item.description: The Duchess of Cornwall, 72, recorded the message marking the anniversary from a Wendy house on the grounds of Birkhall, Aberdeenshire, where she is in isolation with Prince Charles, 72.

item.title: Police arrest two over 201mph Audi RS6 speeding incident
item.description: Police have arrested two men after footage of an Audi RS6 was filmed driving at more than 200mph on the M23 in Sussex.

item.title: Guy's hospital to remove statues of 'slave-trading' benefactor
item.description: Guy's and St Thomas' Hospital Trust revealed that contentious statues of Thomas Guy and Robert Clayton would be removed from view following pressure from Black Lives Matter protesters.

item.title: BBC's Fran Unsworth says Emily Maitlis' rant 'did not belong in an impartial broadcast programme'
item.description: Fran Unsworth defended the BBC's ruling that the controversial introduction to a recent Newsnight episode hosted by Emily Maitlis 'did not meet our standards of due impartiality'.

item.title: Health minister blames NHS Test and Trace problems on people not answering the phone
item.description: Health Minister Edward Argar today blamed the early struggles of the NHS Test and Trace programme on sick people not wanting to pick up the telephone.

item.title: Art Deco apartment once owned by rags-to-riches actor Harry Fowler is on the market for £975,000
item.description: The one-bedroom flat was once owned by 'cheeky cockney' character actor Harry Fowler, who graced British screens for more than 60 years before his death in January 2012, aged 85.

item.title: Kim Jong Un ends relationship with Trump as sanctions continue
item.description: It was the latest in a series of vitriolic statements from Pyongyang aimed at Washington and Seoul, and came a day after they threatened to disrupt US elections if they meddled in inter-Korean affairs.

item.title: Twitter takes down Beijing-backed influence operation pushing coronavirus messages
item.description: Twitter has deleted 170,000 accounts tied to a Beijing-backed influence operation used to spread propaganda linked to coronavirus and Hong Kong.

item.title: Not on our patch! Police called after 'cannabis' is spotted on road
item.description: Worried members of the public called police after spotting plants they believed to be cannabis dumped on a road in Bedale, North Yorkshire.

item.title: Airlines launch legal action against Government's 'flawed' quarantine policy
item.description: The airlines announced they have asked for a judicial review to be heard 'as soon as possible', claiming the measures introduced this week will have a 'devastating effect on British tourism'.
item.media:description: British Airways, easyJet and Ryanair have launched legal action against the Government´s `flawed´ 14-day quarantine policy (Gareth Fuller/PA)

item.title: Coronavirus drive thru testing centre is forced to CLOSE after group of travellers set up camp
item.description: A number of vehicles were seen arriving on Wednesday night at Watford Leisure Centre, the site of the testing facility. Tests had been carried out there on Thursdays and Sundays.

item.title: SpaceX will launch another 60 Starlink satellites into orbit tomorrow
item.description: When launched, this latest batch will bring the size of the Starlink constellation up to 540 satellites, but SpaceX have permission to launch up to 42,000.

item.title: Hilarious moment plumber tumbles into a customer's flowerbed after tripping over plant pot
item.description: Plumber Ricky Cooper, 42, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, was dropping off keys and collecting payment when he took a tumble into a flowerbed suffering minor cuts and bruises.

item.title: Romanian toyboy who inherited 81-year-old husband's cash when he died insists he's no gold digger
item.description: Widow Florin Marin - who is 54 years younger than his late husband - will get £150,000 from a life insurance policy, a £100,000 house, and a £2,000-a-month-for-life pension.

item.title: Woman recreates glamour holiday pictures from home during lockdown and the results are hilarious
item.description: Sharon Waugh, from South Africa, is a travel influencer stranded in her flat due to the coronavirus pandemic. Bored Panda has shared some of the travel snaps she's recreated at home.

item.title: Fraudster who sliced off his own HAND in £6million insurance scam is jailed for two years
item.description: Christian W, 45, a wholesaler from Dortmund, northern Germany, had claimed he tripped and fell under the train in October 2018, causing the gruesome injury.

item.title: Nomadic couple ditch the nine to five to travel Europe in a secondhand van
item.description: Harriet Evans, 28, and Josh Wycherley, 26, who met while working at an adventure camp in Hindhead, Surrey, seven years ago were exploring Europe in a van before lockdown halted them.

item.title: Barbie fanatic who tipped the scales at 340lbs sheds 182lbs after gastric band surgery
item.description: Kayla Lavende's, 35, from Sydney, weight ballooned to 340lbs (24st 4lbs) after she moved to the US. The Barbie fanatic has now had a gastric sleeve and lost a whopping 182lbs (13 st) in just two years.

item.title: Dream £3.5million home featured on Channel 4's Grand Designs is used as set for lesbian PORN film
item.description: The five-bed property in Colgate, West Sussex, which contains a gym, 50ft pool, five bathrooms, underfloor heating and a sauna, was built by businessman Clinton Dall, 56.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... the statue defenders
item.description: 'Beats bob-a-job - AND Akela says we all get our political protesting badges'

item.title: Tower of London bosses plan for garden in the moat to celebrate the Queen's Platinum Jubilee in 2022
item.description: Historic Royal Palaces, which manages the tower, has unveiled an artist's impression of how the moat could look to mark 70 years since the Queen's coronation.

item.title: St Athan is the 'preferred' location for the UK's first gigafactory
item.description: Britishvolt, the frim behind the proposed factory said it has narrowed down its selection from 42 to just two locations, with the site in Wales the 'preferred choice' ahead of one in Coventry.

item.title: Fury as teaching unions celebrate 'victory' of keeping schools closed until September
item.description: Kevin Courtney, the joined head of the NEU, made the comment after Education Secretary Gavin Williamson shelved plans for all primary pupils to return to class before the summer holiday.

item.title: Statue of British naval officer John Hamilton is removed from New Zealand city
item.description: Hamilton mayor Paula Southgate said people found the statue of Captain John Fane Charles Hamilton offensive. He is accused of killing indigenous Maori people in the 1860s.

item.title: Covid-19 victims' families seek probe into handling of pandemic
item.description: Hundreds of victims of Covid-19 are seeking an urgent legal action against the government to start a public inquiry into Boris Johnson's handling of the pandemic in Britain.

item.title: Taxi drivers, security guards and shop workers face regular coronavirus tests
item.description: People without symptoms who work in 'high risk' professions will soon get checked as part of the NHS Test and Trace programme.

item.title: Indian holy man who claimed he could perform 'Covid exorcisms' dies of coronavirus
item.description: The man, from Ratlam in Madhya Pradesh, kissed devotees' hands and said it would rid them of problems - despite the bug spreading through contagious dropets from the mouth and nose.

item.title: Probitoic bacteria could save the Great Barrier Reef's coral
item.description: Feeding coral reefs a dose of 'good' probiotic bacteria - much like that in a pot of yogurt - helps them tolerate rising ocean temperatures, new research is showing.

item.title: Prince Harry says the 'Invictus spirit' is 'even more relevant' as 'we address new challenges'
item.description: Prince Harry, 35, who is currently living in Los Angeles, told organisers of the Invictus Games that the 'spirit' of the contest was 'even more relevant' amid the global coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: India overtakes Britain to become fourth worst country affected by coronavirus
item.description: India has recorded a total of 297,535 cases of coronavirus after reporting 10,956 new infections on Friday, a record on-day increase, leapfrogging Britain which has a total of 292,860 cases.

item.title: 'You cannot lay on the baby!' Dog finds a very unusual place to make itself comfortable
item.description: Juno the dog found a comfortable spot at home in Florida on top of a bump in bed. A woman is heard saying 'You cannot lay on the baby,' which turns out to be a cat.

item.title: Only one in three Britons are worried about catching COVID-19
item.description: One in three adults (35 per cent) admit to being currently worried about becoming infected with COVID-19, while only 15 per cent say the are 'seriously worried'.

item.title: Author recalls growing up with alcoholic dad and drug addict sister in a sink estate in the Nineties
item.description: Fashion journalist and author Lynne Coleman, who lives in Edinburgh, told Femail how she moved to an ex-council house in Auchenback, near Glasgow, when she was six.

item.title: Couple who recently moved house refit whole space for £2k
item.description: Richard Plummer, who lives in Maldon, Essex, with his wife Emma and their three children, decided to embark on a budget lockdown project and shared the results on line.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 77% cases originated in Spain, France and Italy
item.description: Research by the universities of Edinburgh and Oxford found 1,356 different strains of Covid-19 in positive patients in the UK, the genetics of which show they came from different places.

item.title: Brainteaser challenges music fans to name 16 iconic rock stars
item.description: UK-based Rimmers Music has created a brainteaser that challenges music lovers to name the 16 musical acts based on these graphics - but can you beat the five minute record?

item.title: Father stumbles on paramedics trying to save his son's life after road crash appeared on his street
item.description: A father worried that an accident blocking his street had made his son late home was distraught to discover paramedics desperately trying to save the boy's life on the side of the road.

item.title: You've been using your carrot peeler wrong your whole life
item.description: An Australian woman has shocked the internet with a video of herself using a carrot peeler in a very non-traditional way, and even chefs are flawed by the approach.

item.title: Amazing newly colourised images tell the story of how Tutankhamun was unearthed
item.description: Nearly a century after the tomb of 'Boy King' Tutankhamun was uncovered by British archaeologist Howard Carter, the incredible scenes can be seen in full colour for the first time.

item.title: Scientist published a paper in 2010 predicting economic and social turmoil would peak in 2020
item.description: Peter Turchin, a researcher at the University of Connecticut, published a paper in 2010 forecasting that political, economic and social instabilities would peak around the year 2020.

item.title: Man's bizarre garbage bag-changing 'hack' has been viewed 700,000 times
item.description: Chris Lee from LA posted his bag-replacing technique on TikTok on May 31. He tells viewers not to put a fresh back in with the bottom of the bag directly in the bin.

item.title: Twitter may be reviving emoji reactions that let users interact with posts in their timelines
item.description: A screenshot captured by Jane Manchun Wong shows a menu that lets users select one of five emojis that includes a surprised face, an underscored '100' and a laughing face.

item.title: The world's largest cashew tree covers two acres of a park in Brazil and looks like a mini forest
item.description: The tree is located next to an urban beach in Brazil. The limbs of the tree - which is the size of about 70 regular cashew trees - spread out 164ft from the central trunk.

item.title: Church where GH Elliott is buried considers erasing his 'deeply offensive' stage persona
item.description: The Archdeacon of Brighton and Lewes wants to remove the 'deeply offenisve' wording and his grave was today being boarded up while the church decides what steps to take.

item.title: Footballer, 11, who was diagnosed with cancer days receives messages of support from sports stars
item.description: Thomas Cunningham, 11, from Liverpool, who has had trials with Liverpool and Everton, was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin's Lymphoma after complaining that his left ear hurt.

item.title: Former Scouts stop removal of Poole Lord Baden-Powell statue
item.description: Former Scouts today vowed to defend the seaside statue of Robert Baden-Powell due to be hauled down later after Black Lives Matter protesters branded him racist and homophobic.

item.title: Premier League clubs considering Black Lives Matter message instead of names on back of shirts
item.description: With the Premier League returning on June 17, the league is considering the move as well as a Black Lives Matter badge displayed on the front of the matchday shirts, alongside an NHS badge.

item.title: 'Proud working class' woman behind campaign to remove Baden-Powell statue was Corbyn's candidate
item.description: Former Labour candidate Corrie Drew demanded the statue in Poole Quay, Bournemouth be removed and council leader Vikki Slade has said the structure will be taken down 'immediately'.

item.title: Edward Colson statue is hauled from Bristol Harbour
item.description: The Edward Colston monument was toppled during a Black Lives Matter protest in Bristol on Sunday, but police have not yet made any arrests - despite the moment being recorded on film.

item.title: First ever black head of Oxford College calls for statue of Cecil Rhodes to be removed
item.description: Baroness Valerie Amos, who is currently director of London's School of Oriental and African Studies, said that there is no need to glorify Cecil Rhodes with a statue while understanding history.

item.title: Mixed race woman reveals the shocking racism she experienced at secondary school in Plymouth
item.description: Evey Gordon, from Derriford, said in a video shared to the BBC that she felt compelled to speak out 'with everything going on in the world at the moment', but 'couldn't find the words'
